questions.text: A male infant born at 34 weeks of gestation by emergency LSCS was found to have the following finding on histopathological examination of his umbilical cord. Anomalies of which of the following systems are most likely to be found in this infant?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of a  single umbilical artery which is associated with an increased risk for an occult renal anomaly.

The histopathological image of the cross-section of the umbilical cord shows 2 vessels as marked, a thin-walled umbilical vein and a thicker-walled umbilical artery. 

 

The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. Anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries.

Trisomy 18 is a common association.

questions.text: On a particularly busy day in the labor room, you are requested by the PG to take anthropometric measurements and calculate the ponderal index of a baby while she attends to another baby. You find the ponderal index to be 1.45. Which of the following organs is unlikely to be affected in this neonate?
questions.solution:
A ponderal index of <2 suggests asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction. Asymmetric IUGR is associated with a brain-sparing effect, unlike symmetric IUGR, where there is no sparing of head growth.

Ponderal index = Birth weight (gm)/Length (cm)3 x 100.

It is a weight-height-related parameter used as an indicator of fetal growth status.

Symmetric IUGR Asymmetric IUGR
Insult on fetal growth occurs early Insult occurs in late gestation
Head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected Relative sparing of brain growth
A ponderal index greater than or equal to 2  A ponderal index less than 2 
Caused by genetic, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections Caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension, or maternal medical diseases

questions.text: The ponderal index of a term baby delivered by elective cesarean section is 1.75. Which of the following is unlikely to be associated?
questions.solution:
A ponderal index of 1.75 suggests intrauterine growth restriction. Gestational diabetes usually presents with fetal macrosomia.

Maternal factors associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR): 

  • Hypertension/renal disease
  • Diabetes with placental vasculopathy
  • Hypoxemia
  • Malnutrition
  • Chronic illness
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Drugs (narcotics, alcohol, cigarettes, cocaine)
  • Maternal infection and parasite infestations

questions.text: An unbooked primigravida, with no antenatal records, delivers a 2.5kg male baby by normal delivery. While ascertaining the maturity of the child, which of the following would be against a diagnosis of prematurity?
questions.solution:
Thick cartilage with a stiff ear in a newborn is a sign of maturity (not prematurity).

Score Ear
0 Pinna flat and stays folded; no recoil
1 Slightly curved pinna; soft; slow recoil
2 Well-curved pinna; soft but ready recoil
3 Formed & firm, instant recoil
4 Thick cartilage, ear stiff

No creases on the sole, insignificant breast nodule, and empty scrotum are all physical signs of prematurity in a newborn.

Note:

Abundant lanugo hair is not discriminatory evidence of prematurity. This is because neonates of diabetic mothers born as a term or even post-term have abundant lanugo hair, especially over the pinna and upper back.

questions.text: A lady with wrong dates and a corrected gestational age of 43 weeks presents with labor pains. The CTG suggests placental insufficiency, and she is taken up for emergency LSCS. Which of the following physical signs is unlikely to be seen in this neonate?
questions.solution:
The physical sign of an infant born post-term (43 weeks) in association with presumed placental insufficiency is abundant hair (not scanty hair).

Infants born post-term in association with presumed placental insufficiency may have various physical signs, together termed as postmaturity syndrome (or dysmaturity syndrome).

These include:

  1. Desquamation, pale skin, and long nails.
  2. Loose skin around the thighs and buttocks.
  3. Meconium-stained nails, skin, vernix, and umbilical cord.
  4. Presence of placental membranes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady with an obstetric score of G3P2L2 delivers a baby boy at 43 weeks + 2 days period of gestation. Which of the following are unlikely to be associated in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Anemia is not a complication of post-maturity. Polycythemia may be seen in neonates born after 42 weeks of gestation.

Complications of post-maturity include:

  1. Perinatal depression
  2. Meconium aspiration
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension
  4. Hypoglycemia
  5. Hypocalcemia
  6. Polycythemia

questions.text: Immediately following vaginal delivery, a baby is noted to have a diffuse ecchymotic swelling on the scalp. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is caput succedaneum.

Caput succedaneum is a diffuse, sometimes ecchymotic, edematous collection of serosanguinous fluid in the subcutaneous layer of the scalp, involving the presenting part in a vertex delivery. It may extend across the midline and crosses suture lines.

Option A: Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.

Option C: Subgaleal hemorrhages occur with the rupture of emissary veins, which connect the dural sinuses with the superficial veins of the scalp. Blood accumulates between the epicranial aponeurosis of the scalp and the periosteum and resolves over 2-3 weeks. Often associated with vacuum-assisted delivery.

Option D: Epidural hemorrhages, usually traumatic in origin, are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or occur as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of marking B?

choices.text: Swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp
Appears only several hours after birth

questions.solution:
The area marked B represents a cephalohematoma. It is not a swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp.

Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.

Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 2 weeks to 3 months, depending on their size. Cephalohematomas require no treatment, although phototherapy may be necessary to treat the associated hyperbilirubinemia (resorption of blood takes place by the breakdown of RBCs).

 

 

Other markings-

A- Caput succedaneum. It is a diffuse ecchymotic or edematous collection in the soft tissues of the scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears with the first week of life.

C- Sub-galeal hemorrhage. This a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It is a large potential space, thus bleeding can be extensive. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can also occur in hereditary coagulopathies and in association with skull fractures.

D- Epidural hemorrhage. Usually traumatic in origin, these are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: A baby in the postnatal ward is noted to have paralysis of the left hand along with ipsilateral ptosis and miosis. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Klumpke's paralysis associated with Horner syndrome

questions.solution:
Left-hand paralysis with ipsilateral ptosis and miosis in a newborn suggests a diagnosis of Klumpke's paralysis associated with Horner syndrome.

There is an injury to the 7th-8th cervical nerves and the 1st thoracic nerve. This produces a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are mainly affected, and the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1 thoracic root are also injured.

Option A: Erb–Duchenne paralysis affects the 5th and 6th cervical nerves. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination. Moro's reflex is absent on the affected side.

Option B: Phrenic nerve palsy (3, 4, and 5 cervical nerves) results in diaphragmatic paralysis. It is characterized by cyanosis and irregular and labored breathing.

Option C: Horner's syndrome is characterized by miosis, ptosis, enophthalmos, anhydrosis, and loss of ciliospinal reflex.

questions.text: Following a delivery complicated by shoulder dystocia, the baby is noted to have a deformity in the right upper limb. On inspection, the orthopedics JR notes an adducted, internally rotated arm and a pronated forearm. Which nerve roots are affected here?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of Erb–Duchenne paralysis. The injury is limited to the 5th and 6th cervical nerve roots.

The characteristic position consists of adduction and internal rotation of the arm with pronation of the forearm. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination.

There is an asymmetric Moro's Reflex

Note:
In shoulder dystocia, the most common nerve injury is to the C5-6 nerve root. The most common bone to fracture is the clavicle.

questions.text: A term infant develops jaundice at day 2 of life. It first appeared on the sclera and progressed to the trunk by day 4. It completely disappeared by day 7 following phototherapy. Which of the following statements is false regarding the cause of this pattern of jaundice?

choices.text: Due to a rise in unconjugated bilirubin
Due to limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver
Due to Rh incompatibility between maternal and fetal red blood cells
Due to increased breakdown of fetal red blood cells

questions.solution:
The above pattern of jaundice is suggestive of physiological jaundice/icterus neonatorum. It is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver.

It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd day, usually peaks on the 4th day at 5–6 mg/dL, and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth.

Rh incompatibility between maternal and fetal red blood cells leads to pathological jaundice.

 

Note:  

Depth of jaundice (degree of yellowness) should be carefully noted (light staining as lemon-yellow; deep staining as orange-yellow), as it is an important indicator of the level of jaundice. Earlier, the involvement of soles and palms indicated severe jaundice but deep yellow staining (even in absence of yellow soles or palms) may be associated with severe jaundice.

questions.text: A male infant with a birth weight of 3.2 Kg is admitted to the phototherapy unit with a total bilirubin of 11mg/dl at 36 hours of life. Which of the following statements does not describe pathological jaundice?

choices.text: Jaundice appears within first 24 hours after birth
Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks
Jaundice associated with rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dl/24 hour
Jaundice seen in the mid-abdomen and soles

questions.solution:
Jaundice associated with a rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dL/24 hours suggests physiological jaundice.

Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:

  • Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth
  • Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant
  • Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level
  • Total serum bilirubin levels above the expected normal range; jaundice seen in the mid-abdominal region (≈ 15 mg/dL) and soles (≈ 20 mg/dL)
  • Total serum bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy
  • Total serum bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a newborn baby girl sent on day 2 of life shows mild hemolysis. What is the most common cause of this finding in a newborn?
questions.solution:
ABO incompatibility is the most common cause of hemolytic disease of newborns and affects the firstborn. It is usually mild and subclinical.

This incompatibility between the mother and fetus generally results in milder disease than Rh incompatibility does. 

It arises when a mother with blood group type O becomes pregnant with a fetus of different blood type (A/B). The mother's serum contains naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B, which can cross the placenta and cause hemolysis of fetal RBCs.

Although antibodies against A and B factors occur without previous immunization (natural antibodies), they are usually IgM, which do not cross the placenta. However, IgG antibodies to A antigen may be present, and these do cross the placenta, resulting in A-O iso-immune hemolytic disease in the first-born infant (A-O is more common than B-O).

questions.text: A 3.3 Kg term neonate is admitted on day 3 of life with yellowish discoloration of the skin and is going to undergo phototherapy. What is the most effective wavelength of light used for treatment?
questions.solution:
The most effective range of wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia is 460–490 nm (blue-green light).

Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by 3 mechanisms:

  • Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state.
  • Reversible photo-isomerization reaction: converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation.
  • Photo-oxidation: minor method

 

Blue-green light (460 to 490 nm) is more effective than blue light (430 to 470 nm) due to the following reasons:

  • Blue-green light preferentially favors the formation of lumirubin
  • Its longer wavelength (460 to 490 nm) enhances skin penetration
  • Pure blue light can mask cyanosis in an infant

Note:

Phototherapy is effective only when bilirubin is accumulated in the skin. There is no role of prophylactic phototherapy in mild/ sub-clinical jaundice. 

Contraindication of phototherapy: Porphyria.

questions.text: A mother noticed yellowish discoloration of her term newborn within the first 6 hours of life. On examination, jaundice extended up to the lower abdomen and thighs. Which of the following drugs can be administered along with phototherapy?
questions.solution:
Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical therapy for pathological jaundice in neonates.

It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is receiving phototherapy.

Tolazoline is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that produces systemic and pulmonary vasodilatation, which is used to correct pulmonary artery vasospasm when it causes severe right-left shunting soon after birth.

Tromethamine is an organic buffer used in the management of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: While on rounds in the postnatal ward, the senior PG shows you a baby with dark, grayish-brown skin discoloration. It is a term, AGA baby on day 7 of life. She tells you that it is a case of bronze baby syndrome. This syndrome is caused by:
questions.solution:
The bronze baby syndrome is a dark, grayish-brown skin discoloration in infants undergoing phototherapy; it mainly occurs in infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia as an adverse effect of phototherapy.

Despite the bronze baby syndrome, phototherapy can continue if needed.

Other complications of Phototherapy: 

  1. Loose stools
  2. Erythematous macular rash
  3. The purpuric rash associated with transient porphyrinemia
  4. Overheating
  5. Dehydration (increased insensible water loss, diarrhea)
  6. Hypothermia from exposure

Gray baby syndrome is an adverse effect of chloramphenicol. 

Redman syndrome is an adverse effect of vancomycin.

questions.text: A 3.2 Kg term neonate born to a primigravida with gestational diabetes presented to the OPD with complaints of lethargy, hypotonia, and difficulty in feeding. Periodic monitoring of blood glucose is being done. What blood glucose levels indicate a need for the treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
The cut-off for the treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia to start IV glucose is a blood glucose level of <40 mg/dL.

Neonatal hypoglycemia can be suspected when the blood glucose is <45 mg/dL. Clinically in neonates, hypoglycemia can be asymptomatic or symptomatic. The neonate presents with tremors, cyanosis, convulsions, apneic spells, tachypnea, weak and high-pitched cry, lethargy, difficulty in feeding, episodes of sweating, sudden pallor, hypothermia, and rarely cardiac arrest.

Management in symptomatic neonates:

  • Blood glucose <40mg/dL: IV glucose infusion
  • Blood glucose <25mg/dL: Bolus IV dextrose 1-2 mL/kg followed by infusion at the rate of 5-8mL/kg/min.

Management in asymptomatic neonates:

  • Breastfeeding within 30 minutes
  • Start IV glucose therapy if blood glucose <35 mg/dL
  • Recheck blood glucose before the next feeding
  • Continue skin-to-skin care
  • Evaluation for other underlying illnesses

The desired target glucose value is >50mg/dL and blood glucose should be rechecked until three normal values.

questions.text: After the delivery of an infant of a diabetic mother, the blood glucose of the Infant was 60 mg/dl. Which other investigation would you do?
questions.solution:
In an infant of a diabetic mother with normal blood glucose levels, the next investigation to consider is serum calcium due to the high risk of developing hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia in these infants is attributed to the delayed response of the parathyroid hormone system. 

Hypocalcemia is defined as a total serum calcium concentration of less than 8 mg/dL for a term baby (ionized calcium below 4mg/dL) and less than 7 mg/dL for a preterm baby. Asymptomatic neonates can be managed conservatively with early nutrition. Symptomatic neonates should receive iv or oral calcium replacement. 

Maternal hyperglycemia causes fetal hyperglycemia, and the fetal pancreatic response leads to fetal hyperinsulinemia, which causes neonatal hypoglycemia. Neonatal hypoglycemia is defined as blood glucose <40 mg/dL (plasma glucose <45 mg/dL). The infant tends to be jittery, tremulous, hyperexcitable, hypotonic, lethargic, and poor sucking during the 1st three days after birth. These symptoms can also be related to hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia which occur in the 1st 24 to 72 hours of life. 

Respiratory distress syndrome, macrosomia, hyperbilirubinemia, polycythemia, renal vein thrombosis, visceromegaly, heart failure, and persistent pulmonary hypertension are other features seen in infants of diabetic mothers. 

Congenital anomalies are seen in infants of mothers with pregestational diabetes. Neural tube defects (Encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), transposition of great vessels (TGA), ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen. 

Caudal regression syndrome is rare, but a specific anomaly seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following problems may be associated with the baby born to this lady?
  1. Hyperglycemia
  2. Hypocalcemia
  3. Neural tube defects
  4. Macrosomia
  5. Tetrology of Fallot
questions.solution:
Infants born to diabetic mothers may present with macrosomia (large for gestational age), hypocalcemia, and/ or neural tube defects.

Other common features include: 

  1. Hypoglycemia
  2. Respiratory distress syndrome
  3. Cardiomegaly
  4. Heart failure
  5. Lumbosacral agenesis
  6. Cardiac malformations
    1. Ventricular or atrial septal defect
    2. Transposition of the great vessels (most specific)
    3. Truncus arteriosus
    4. Double-outlet right ventricle
    5. Tricuspid atresia
    6. Coarctation of the aorta

Additional anomalies include neural tube defects, hydronephrosis, renal agenesis and dysplasia, duodenal or anorectal atresia, situs inversus, double ureter, and holoprosencephaly.
